metadata.case_name: Unni v. State of Kerala & Rajwant Singh v. State of Kerala

facts.text: Death of Lt. Commander Menianha of Naval Base, I.N.S. Vendurthy, Willingdon Island, Cochin Harbour, on the night of March 30, 1963.
Unni attached as a rating to Naval Base and on leave at time of offence; Taylor ex-sailor; Rajwant Singh attached to I.N.S. Vikrant.
Appellants conspired to burgle safe of Base Supply Office on eve of pay-day when large sum kept there.
Collected articles: Naval Officers dress, bottle of chloroform, hacksaw with spare blades, adhesive plaster, cotton wool, ropes.
Decoyed Lt. Commander from house on pretext wanted at Naval Base; in lonely place caught hold of him.

Covered mouth with adhesive plaster, tied handkerchief over it, plugged nostrils with cotton wool soaked in chloroform; tied hands and legs with rope; deposited in shallow drain with own shirt under head as pillow.
Went to sentry, induced to part with rifle by accused dressed as officer, attacked sentry who raised hue and cry, attracted watchman; released sentry and fled.
Sentry informed Officer-on-duty, recognised Rajwant Singh as assailant.
Next morning, dead body of Lt. Commander discovered in drain.
Investigation followed; five persons tried before Sessions Judge, Ernakulam; three convicted (Unni, Rajwant Singh, Taylor), two acquitted.
Unni sentenced to death; Rajwant Singh to imprisonment for life and 4 years RI under ss.392/394 concurrent; Taylor to life imprisonment aggregate.
Kerala High Court judgments dated October 12, 1964 dismissed appeals, confirmed death on Unni.

Inquest and postmortem: legs tied with rope, arms tied behind back, large adhesive plaster sealed mouth completely, handkerchief tied over, nostrils plugged with cotton soaked in chloroform; death due to asphyxiation.
Confession by Rajwant Singh before Sub-Magistrate, Cochin: graphically describes part played by him and Unni; intended only to keep unconscious while rifling safe.
Victim placed in drain by assailants with folded shirt under head; had fainted; no awareness of presence otherwise earlier discovery.

legal_issues.text: Whether the evidence establishes offence of murder or only causing grievous hurt or culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
Whether s.34 IPC could be used against the accused.
Whether sentence of death on Unni proper, as case indistinguishable from others.

petitioner_arguments.text: Acts show no intention to kill but to render unconscious; closing mouth and plugging nostrils with chloroform-soaked cotton to immobilise and silence while rifling safe.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.299 clauses 1-3; s.304 Pt II IPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Offence at worst culpable homicide not amounting to murder u/s 304 Pt II; appellants knew acts likely to cause death but no intention to kill or cause likely fatal injury.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.300 IPC clauses do not apply

petitioner_arguments.text: s.34 IPC could not be used against accused.
Sentence of death on Unni not proper as case indistinguishable from Rajwant Singh and Taylor.
Sufficiency of injury to cause death in ordinary course must be proved separately, not inferred from death; concentration/quantity of chloroform, cotton wool manner needed proof.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants' complicity established; acts resulted in death by asphyxiation.

court_reasoning.text: Acts resulted in death; cannot be lower than culpable homicide as appellants knew likely to kill; question is murder or culpable homicide.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Short question whether offence murder or culpable homicide.

court_reasoning.text: s.300 clause 1 (intention to cause death) not apply: no preparation or contemplation to kill; confession shows surprise at death.
s.300 clause 2 (intention to cause bodily injury known likely to cause death) not apply: intended to render unconscious, no subjective knowledge of fatal consequences tantamount to intention to kill.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No subjective foresight of death as murder intention.

court_reasoning.text: s.300 clause 3 applies: bodily injury (tying hands/feet, sealing mouth, plugging nostrils with chloroform cotton) sufficient in ordinary course of nature to cause death; deliberate, preplanned; victim helpless; death direct result, no intervening cause.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Injury objectively sufficient to cause death; Virsa Singh test satisfied.

court_reasoning.text: No need for further proof of chloroform concentration etc. as death due to asphyxiation from assailants' acts alone; sufficiency established by acts and consequence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Where victim helpless and death from offender's act alone, acts and causal connection suffice.

court_reasoning.text: Possibly clause 4 also (imminently dangerous act likely to cause death), but unnecessary.
Common intention admits no doubt; all acts deliberate after discussion; s.34 applies as shared intention to cause sufficient injury; even if abettors, liable u/s 113 IPC.
Unni master mind; death sentence appropriate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reason to interfere with death sentence on Unni.

holdings.text: Offence is murder u/s 302/34 IPC; falls within clause thirdly of s.300 IPC.
s.34 IPC applicable due to common intention.
Death sentence on Unni appropriate as master mind.

precedents_cited.case_name: Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for s.300 clause 3: establish injury, its sufficiency objectively, intention to inflict that injury.
Emphasis on sufficiency of injury in ordinary course to cause death for clause thirdly.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under 302/34 for murder with common intention; analysis of 299/300 to distinguish culpable homicide from murder; 304 Pt II alternative argued but rejected.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; convictions and sentences under ss.302/34 etc. confirmed; no interference with death sentence on Unni or life on Rajwant Singh.

key_quotes.text: "The bodily injury consisted of tying up the hands and feet of the victim, closing the mouth with adhesive plaster and plugging the nostrils with cotton soaked in chloroform. All these acts were deliberate acts which had been preplanned."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes deliberate intention for s.300 clause 3.

key_quotes.text: "Death of the victim took place as a direct result of the acts of his assailants... The bodily injury proved fatal in the ordinary course of nature."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms objective sufficiency of injury under s.300 thirdly.

key_quotes.text: "We accordingly hold that the offence was murder."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on nature of offence.
